revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
revision.text:
'''Eddie Germano''' (born 1924) is a cartoonist who is best known for his sports cartoons.<ref name="Eddie Germano">[http://eddiegermano.net/ Eddie Germano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723104812/http://eddiegermano.net/ |date=2011-07-23 }} Eddie Germano, 2007, Retrieved 10/1/2010</ref>
==Biography== Eddie Germano was born in [[Boston]], Massachusetts on November 15, 1924. He started working at an office of the [[Boston Post]] at age 16.<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons">[http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/g/germano_e.htm#d0e141 Eddie Germano Cartoons] Syracuse University, 23 Sep 2009, Retrieved 10/1/2010</ref> After serving in the Army,got his first full-time position as a cartoonist in 1948. He then worked at several Massachusetts and Florida newspapers. In 1963 he joined the staff of the [[Brockton Enterprise]] in order to create sports and editorial cartoons for the publication. At age 66, Germano left the ''Enterprise'' to pursue freelance work.<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons"/> Germano continues to draw privately commissioned cartoons.<ref name="Eddie Germano"/> He has six granddaughters: Jaclyn Germano, Jennifer Germano, Julia Germano, Justina Germano, Anna Germano, and Maria Ducey as well as 3 grandsons: Edward Germano, Michael Germano, and Harry Germano.
==Career== Besides working at newspapers, Germano also worked on numerous cartoon projects. He acted as producer on a cartoon television show for three years. In 1971 Germano began contributing special cartoon sports features for the [[Boston Globe]].<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons"/>
During the 1990s, Germano worked with [[Tom McCormick]] on Mr. Speaker, a strip that is unpublished. Some of his cartoons have also been displayed at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York.<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons"/>
==Books== Germano's cartoons often feature Boston's sports teams. In 1989 his book ''Red Sox Drawing Board'' was published.<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons"/>
==Awards== He won the [[National Cartoonist Society]] Sports Cartoon Award in 1981 and 1992.<ref>[http://www.reuben.org/divisions.html National Cartoonists Society] 2008, Retrieved 10/1/2010</ref> Germano also won an award for his cartoon series on heavyweight boxer [[Rocky Marciano]], who grew up in [[Brockton, MA]].<ref name="Eddie Germano Cartoons"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110723104812/http://eddiegermano.net/ Eddie Germano] *[http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/g/germano_e.htm#d0e84 Eddie Germano Cartoons 1964-1968] at Syracuse University (primary source material) *[http://www.reuben.org/divisions.html NCS Awards]
